facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2 of 1954. Appeal under article 132  1

facts.text: Appeal under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under article 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 10th September, 1953,

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 10th September 1953 of High Court of Judicature at Nagpur in Miscellaneous Petition No. 123 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Order dated the 10th September, 1953, of the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur in Miscellaneous Petition No. 123 of 1953. C. Setalvad,

facts.text: Judgment delivered on 1954 May 13 by Venkatarama Aiyar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. May 13. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J-The point for decision in this appeal is whether a Resolution

facts.text: Resolution of Government of Central Provinces and Berar dated 16th September 1948 fixed scale of dearness allowance to its servants.

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision in this appeal is whether a Resolution of the Government of Central Provinces and Berar, number Madhya Pradesh, dated 16th September, 1948, fixing a -scale of dearness allowance to be paid to its servants is repugnant to article 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Phenomenal rise in price of foodstuffs and essential commodities consequent on the war.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances under which the above Resolution came to be adopted may be briefly mentioned. Consequent on the war, there was a phenomenal rise in the price of foodstuffs and of other essential companymodities,

facts.text: Government servants worst hit by price rise.

anchor.surface_text: and of other essential companymodities, and among the persons worst hit by it were the Government servants.

facts.text: Central and Provincial Governments sanctioned grain allowances in 1940.

anchor.surface_text: As a measure of relief to them, the Central and the Provincial Governments sanctioned a grant of grain allowances to them under various Resolutions passed in 1940.

facts.text: Central Government employees received same benefit as respective Provincial Government employees.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme adopted by the Central Government was that its employees stationed in various Provinces received the same benefit as the respective Provincial Government employees.

facts.text: Central Pay Commission appointed on 10th May 1946.

anchor.surface_text: But this scheme was found to be unsuitable for employees of the Central Government, as the allowances granted by the Provincial Governments were number uniform. On 10th May, 1946, the Central Government appointed a Central Pay Commission,

facts.text: Central Pay Commission report dated 3rd May 1947 recommended dearness allowance on specified scale.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission, which was presided over by Sir S. Varadachariar, recommended by its report dated 3rd May, 1947, the grant of dearness allowance on a specified scale.

facts.text: Government of Central Provinces and Berar appointed Pay Committee on 27th May 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On 27th May, 1947, the Government of Central Provinces and Berar appointed a Pay Committee, hereinafter referred to as the Committee,

facts.text: Pay Committee report dated 22nd June 1948 recommended dearness allowance scale less than Central for salaries Rs. 400 or less.

anchor.surface_text: By its report dated 22nd June, 1948, the Committee recommended the grant of dearness allowance on a scale which, though practically identical with that adopted by the Commission in respect of salaries above Rs. 400 per mensem, was less than it as regards salaries of Rs. 400 per mensem or less.

facts.text: Recommendations accepted by Resolution dated 16th September 1948.

anchor.surface_text: These recommendations were accepted by the Government by its Resolution dated 16th September, 1948.

facts.text: Employees filed application under article 226 through respondent.

anchor.surface_text: This difference in the result between the two scales number unnaturally caused companysiderable dissatisfaction among the employees companycerned, and after unsuccessful attempts to get redress on the executive side, they filed through their representative, the respondent, the present application under article 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petition alleged discrimination in DA for salaries below and above Rs. 400 compared to Central rates.

anchor.surface_text: In the petition it was alleged that the State Government should have uniformly adopted the Government of India rates for all its servants and the discrimination in making the two-fold slab and accepting the Government of India rates for one slab, i.e., for servants receiving salary over Rs. 400, and number accepting them in respect of the other slab, i.e., of servants drawing below Rs. 400, is highly discri- minatory,

facts.text: High Court (Sinha CJ and Bhutt J) held claim justiciable and Resolution violated article 14, directed reconsideration.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges  Sinha C.J. and Bhutt J.  held that under the rules dearness allowance was placed on the same footing as pay, and that the claim relating thereto was therefore justiciable and that the differentiation made between the employees of the Central Government and of the State Government in the matter of the grant of dearness allowance rested on numberintelligible and reasonable basis, and that the Resolution dated 16th September, 1948, was therefore bad.

facts.text: Appeal preferred by State Government on certificate under article 132(1).

anchor.surface_text: They accordingly issued a direction to the State Government that they do reconsider the question of dearness allowance payable to the employees companycerned. It is against this judgment that the present appeal has been preferred by the State Government on a certificate granted under article 132 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court held dearness allowance grant is discretionary under Rule 44 FR, not justiciable.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both these companytention are well founded On the first question, Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules runs as follow Subject to any restrictions which the Secretary of State in Council may by order impose upon the powers of the Governor-General in Council or the Governor in Council, as the case may be, and to the general rule that the amount of a companypensatory allowance should be so regulated that the allowance is number on the whole a source of profit to the recipient, a Local Government may grant such allowance to any Government servant under its companytrol and may make rules prescribing their amounts and the companyditions under which they may be drawn.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Resolution not repugnant to article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that the scale of dearness allowance recommended by the Commission and sanctioned by the Central Government can furnish numberground for holding that the scale of dearness allowance recommended by the Committee and adopted by the appellant is repugnant to article 14.

facts.text: Pay Committee adopted different basis than Central Commission: current prices, revised basic pay, financial resources.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 80 of the Report the Committee observed that while the Commission based its scale on the companyt of living index, they themselves adopted the current level of prices as the basis for fixation of dearness allowance. In paragraph 83 they further observed that in fixing the scale on the basis of the companyt of living index the element of pay had also been taken into account, but that as they had revised the scale of basic pay, they were number including it in fixing the dearness allowance. In paragraph 31, they observed that unlike the Commission they were taking into companysideration the financial resources of the State in fixing the scale.

facts.text: State Government passed Resolutions on 4th January 1951 and 6th October 1951 adopting Central scale for certain categories.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Nambiar also referred us to two Resolutions of the appellant dated 4th January, 195 1, and 6th October, 195 1, adopting the scale fixed by the Commission in respect of certain other categories.

facts.text: Petitioner prayed for writ declaring entitlement to GOI DA rates or adequate DA.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then prayed That declaring that all ministerial servants are entitled to the Government of India rates of Dearness Allowance or in any case adequate Dearness Allowance, the State Government should be directed by a writ of mandamus or by any other suitable writ or direction to cancel the discriminatory rules of Dearness Allowance and adopt the Government of India rates to all servants without discrimination or in any case, to provide with adequate rates of Dearness Allowance sufficient to provide reasonable subsistence for them.

facts.text: Government contested petition: claim not justiciable, no violation of art 14.

anchor.surface_text: The Government companytested the petition on the grounds, firstly, that the claim for dearness allowance was number justiciable, and secondly, that the difference in the scales of dearness allowance adopted by the Commission and by the Committee did number violate article 14.

The point for decision in this appeal is whether a Resolution of the Government of Central Provinces and Berar, number Madhya Pradesh, dated 16th September, 1948, fixing a -scale of dearness allowance to be paid to its servants is repugnant to article 14 of the Constitution.

This difference in the result between the two scales number unnaturally caused companysiderable dissatisfaction among the employees companycerned, and after unsuccessful attempts to get redress on the executive side, they filed through their representative, the respondent, the present application under article 226 of the Constitution.
Appeal under article 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 10th September, 1953,

anchor.surface_text: Under the Constitution, the Union and the States are distinct entities, each having its own executive and Legislature, with their powers well-defined. Article 12 defines the State as including the Government and the Legislature of each of the States.

Article 13 2  enacts that the State shall number make any laws taking away, or abridging the rights companyferred by Part III, and article 14 enacts that, The State shall number deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.

arguments.claim: Partial adoption of Commission rates by Committee (for >400 but not <=400) constitutes discrimination under Art 14

anchor.surface_text: His contention is that the Committee whose recommendations were accepted by the Government adopted the rates suggested in the report of the Commission as regards Government servants who drew a monthly salary of. over Rs. 400, but when they came to those employees who drew a monthly salary of Rs. 400 or less, they discarded the rates fixed by the Commission, and, instead, adopted different and lower rates, and that this was discrimination hit by article 14.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 364 Ex. Ch. at P- 387- of the rate from the lowest to the highest category. No companytention is raised that fixing different rates of dearness allowa

arguments.court_reasoning: Art 14 prohibits discrimination by same state; cannot compare Union and State laws

arguments.claim: Art 14 does not permit invalidating state resolution by comparison to central commission report; distinct authorities under Art 12,13(2)

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the impugned Resolution, though valid in itself as not infringing article 14, becomes void under that provision when it is taken in conjunction with the report of the Commission. We do not find anything in article 14 which supports this somewhat startling contention. Under the Constitution, the Union and the States are distinct entities, each having its own executive and Legislature, with their powers well-defined.

arguments.claim: Committee did not partially adopt Commission report; used different basis (current prices, revised pay, state finances)

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 80 of the Report the Committee observed that while the Commission based its scale on the cost of living index, they themselves adopted the current level of prices as the basis for fixation of dearness allowance. In paragraph 83 they further observed that in fixing the scale on the basis of the cost of living index the element of pay had also been taken into account, but that as they had revised the scale of basic pay, they were not including it in fixing the dearness allowance.

holdings.text: Grant of dearness allowance under Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules is a discretionary matter ex gratia and not justiciable; neither writ of mandamus nor any direction can be issued to compel its grant.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both these contentions are well founded On the first question, Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules runs as follow Subject to any restrictions which the Secretary of State in Council may by order impose upon the powers of the Governor-General in Council or the Governor in Council, as the case may be, and to the general rule that the amount of a compensatory allowance should be so regulated that the allowance is not on the whole a source of profit to the recipient, a Local Government may grant such allowance to any Government servant under its control and may make rules prescribing their amounts and the conditions under which they may be drawn. Under this provision, it is a matter of discretion with the local Government whether it will grant dearness allowance and if so, how much.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 44 confers discretion on government to grant compensatory allowances like DA without creating enforceable right or duty; distinguishes arrears of salary (justiciable as debt per Tara Chand) from prospective discretionary grants; no petition of right lies for matters of grace.

holdings.text: A government resolution fixing scale of dearness allowance under Rule 44 constitutes 'law' as defined in Article 13(3)(a) and is subject to Article 14 scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Nambiar [...] did not dispute the correctness of this position. But he argued that when once the Government passed a Resolution fixing a scale of allowance under Rule 44, that would be law as defined in article 13 3 a of the Constitution, and if that law infringed, article 14, it could be declared void. That is a contention which is clearly open to him, and the question therefore that falls to be decided is whether the Resolution dated 16th September, 1948, is bad as infringing article 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts respondent's argument that executive resolution under FR 44 qualifies as 'law' under Art 13(3)(a), opening it to constitutional challenge under Art 14.

holdings.text: The scheme in the Resolution providing graded dearness allowance by pay slabs with progressive reduction and minor city-based adjustment does not discriminate and does not infringe Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the scheme which has been adopted in the impugned Resolution is firstly that dearness allowance is to be paid to the employees on a scale graded according to pay, different rates being adopted for different slabs and there being a progressive reduction of the rate from the lowest to the highest category. [...] These being the features of the scheme, there can be no room for the contention that it has made any discrimination.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification by pay slabs is reasonable and uniform within slabs (except unimpugned city adjustment); satisfies Art 14 reasonable classification test.

holdings.text: Article 14 does not permit invalidation of a State law/resolution by comparing it to a Union/another State's law on similar subject; Union and States are distinct entities whose laws are evaluated independently.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Nambiar does not contend that there is anything in the scheme or in the Resolution adopting it, which brings it within the prohibition enacted in article 14. His contention is that the Committee [...] discarded the rates fixed by the Commission, and, instead, adopted different and lower rates, and that this was discrimination hit by article 14. In other words, the impugned Resolution, though valid in itself as not infringing article 14, becomes void under that provision when it is taken in conjunction with the report of the Commission. We do not find anything in article 14 which supports this somewhat startling contention. Under the Constitution, the Union and the States are distinct entities [...]. The result, therefore, is that the scale of dearness allowance recommended by the Commission and sanctioned by the Central Government can furnish no ground for holding that the scale of dearness allowance recommended by the Committee and adopted by the appellant is repugnant to article 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 12 defines State separately; Art 13(2)/14 apply to laws of individual State; no provision for comparative invalidity across federal entities; hypothetical joint legislation possible only within same legislature.

holdings.text: The State Pay Committee did not partially adopt the Central Pay Commission's dearness allowance scale but independently adopted different basis considering current prices, revised basic pay, and state financial resources.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 80 of the Report the Committee observed that while the Commission based its scale on the cost of living index, they themselves adopted the current level of prices as the basis for fixation of dearness allowance. In paragraph 83 they further observed that in fixing the scale on the basis of the cost of living index the element of pay had also been taken into account, but that as they had revised the scale of basic pay, they were not including it in fixing the dearness allowance. In paragraph 31, they observed that unlike the Commission they were taking into consideration the financial resources of the State in fixing the scale. Thus, the Committee approached the problem from a different angle [...]

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpretation of Committee's report (paras 31,80,83) shows distinct methodology despite superficial similarities; later resolutions irrelevant.

precedents.citation: The Punjab Province v. pandit Tara Chand

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab Province v. pandit Tara Chand 1  that the present claim was justiciable. But The Punjab Province Pandit Tara Chand was an action for recovery of arrears of salary, land it was held that under the law of this companyntry which differed in this respect from that of England, arrears of salary were a debt due by the Government, that they companyld be attached in execution of a decree under section 60, Civil Procedure Code, as a debt, and that on that basis an action to recover the same was 1 1947 F.C.R. 89.

precedents.case_name: Punjab Province v. Pandit Tara Chand
precedents.cited_proposition: arrears of salary were a debt due by the Government and an action to recover the same was maintainable
precedents.cited_holding: under the law of this country which differed in this respect from that of England, arrears of salary were a debt due by the Government, that they could be attached in execution of a decree under section 60, Civil Procedure Code, as a debt, and that on that basis an action to recover the same was maintainable

outcome.relief_summary: Grant of dearness allowance is ex gratia and not justiciable; Resolution dated 16th September 1948 not hit by Article 14

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both these contentions are well founded On the first question, Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules runs as follow Subject to any restrictions which the Secretary of State in Council may by order impose upon the powers of the Governor-General in Council or the Governor in Council, as the case may be, and to the general rule that the amount of a compensatory allowance should be so regulated that the allowance is not on the whole a source of profit to the recipient, a Local Government may grant such allowance to any Government servant under its control and may make rules prescribing their amounts and the conditions under which they may be drawn. Under this provision, it is a matter of discretion with the local Government whether it will grant dearness allowance and if so, how much.

In our opinion, both these contentions are well founded On the first question, Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules runs as follow Subject to any restrictions which the Secretary of State in Council may by order impose upon the powers of the Governor-General in Council or the Governor in Council, as the case may be, and to the general rule that the amount of a compensatory allowance should be so regulated that the allowance is not on the whole a source of profit to the recipient, a Local Government may grant such allowance to any Government servant under its control and may make rules prescribing their amounts and the conditions under which they may be drawn.

Mr. Nambiar [...] did not dispute the correctness of this position. But he argued that when once the Government passed a Resolution fixing a scale of allowance under Rule 44, that would be law as defined in article 13 3 a of the Constitution, and if that law infringed, article 14, it could be declared void. That is a contention which is clearly open to him, and the question therefore that falls to be decided is whether the Resolution dated 16th September, 1948, is bad as infringing article 14.

In our opinion, both these contentions are well founded On the first question, Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules runs as follow Subject to any restrictions which the Secretary of State in Council may by order impose upon the powers of the Governor-General in Council or the Governor in Council, as the case may be, and to the general rule that the amount of a compensatory allowance should be so regulated that the allowance is not on the whole a source of profit to the recipient, a Local Government may grant such allowance to any Government servant under its control and may make rules prescribing their amounts and the conditions under which they may be drawn.

edges.explanation: The holding that the Resolution's scheme of graded dearness allowance does not discriminate directly addresses and resolves the issue of whether the Resolution fixing the scale infringes Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the scheme which has been adopted in the impugned Resolution is firstly that dearness allowance is to be paid to the employees on a scale graded according to pay, different rates being adopted for different slabs and there being a progressive reduction of the rate from the lowest to the highest category. [...] These being the features of the scheme, there can be no room for the contention that it has made any discrimination.

In our opinion, both these contentions are well founded On the first question, Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules runs as follow Subject to any restrictions which the Secretary of State in Council may by order impose upon the powers of the Governor-General in Council or the Governor in Council, as the case may be, and to the general rule that the amount of a compensatory allowance should be so regulated that the allowance is not on the whole a source of profit to the recipient, a Local Government may grant such allowance to any Government servant under its control and may make rules prescribing their amounts and the conditions under which they may be drawn.

edges.explanation: The holding prohibiting invalidation of the State Resolution by comparison to Union or other State laws under Article 14 addresses the issue by rejecting comparative discrimination arguments against the Resolution.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Nambiar does not contend that there is anything in the scheme or in the Resolution adopting it, which brings it within the prohibition enacted in article 14. His contention is that the Committee [...] discarded the rates fixed by the Commission, and, instead, adopted different and lower rates, and that this was discrimination hit by article 14. In other words, the impugned Resolution, though valid in itself as not infringing article 14, becomes void under that provision when it is taken in conjunction with the report of the Commission. We do not find anything in article 14 which supports this somewhat startling contention. Under the Constitution, the Union and the States are distinct entities [...]. The result, therefore, is that the scale of dearness allowance recommended by the Commission and sanctioned by the Central Government can furnish no ground for holding that the scale of dearness allowance recommended by the Committee and adopted by the appellant is repugnant to article 14.

In our opinion, both these contentions are well founded On the first question, Rule 44 of the Fundamental Rules runs as follow Subject to any restrictions which the Secretary of State in Council may by order impose upon the powers of the Governor-General in Council or the Governor in Council, as the case may be, and to the general rule that the amount of a compensatory allowance should be so regulated that the allowance is not on the whole a source of profit to the recipient, a Local Government may grant such allowance to any Government servant under its control and may make rules prescribing their amounts and the conditions under which they may be drawn.
